metadata.title: Foundations for the Study of Structure and Function of Proteins

body_text.text: DNA, RNA, proteins, etc. are the basic components of life. DNA is the vector of genetic information and is transcribed into RNA which is in turn translated into protein. Protein is the expression of genetic information, the performer of kinds of biological functions, and the sustainer of metabolic activities in the organisms. Protein plays an important role in the whole processes of life, including the appearance of life to the growth of life to apoptosis.
body_text.section: Importance of Protein ::: Introduction

body_text.text: There are two examples illustrating the importance of protein. The first one is about the SARS. One protein is found to increase the self-copy efficiency for 100 times or so, which makes the viruses propagate at a high rate. Another example is a flu virus protein whose structure looks like a narrow-neck bag. This strange structure of the protein can help the virus resist drugs.
body_text.section: Importance of Protein ::: Introduction

body_text.text: What should we study? What is the core problem? How can we study? What is most remarkable is that cells can produce proteins with strikingly different properties and activities by joining the same 20 amino acids in many different combinations and sequences. Nowadays, biologists study protein from these aspects: structure and function, the transfer of information.
body_text.section: Protein Research: What to Study and How to Study? ::: Amino Acids, Peptides, and Proteins ::: Introduction

body_text.text: All 20 standard amino acids found in proteins are α-amino acids. Figure 10.1 shows the structure formula of α-amino acids. Each amino acid has a different side chain (or R group, R = “remainder of the molecule”) and is given a three-letter abbreviation and a one-letter symbol. Biologists often use the first three letters or the first letter. The 20 amino acids of proteins are often referred to as the standard amino acids. All proteins in all species (from bacteria to human) are constructed from the same set of 20 amino acids. All proteins, no matter how different they are in structure and function, are made of the 20 standard amino acids. Figure 10.1 shows the structure formulae of all the 20 amino acids.
body_text.section: Amino Acid ::: Amino Acids, Peptides, and Proteins ::: Introduction

body_text.text: Protein structures are studied at primary, secondary, tertiary, and quaternary levels. There are tight correlations among these levels.
body_text.section: Protein Structure Hierarchy ::: Amino Acids, Peptides, and Proteins ::: Introduction

body_text.text: From the aspect of chemical structures of proteins, proteins can be classified into two classes. If proteins are completely composed of amino acids, these proteins are called simple proteins, such as insulin; if there are other components, they are named conjugated proteins like hemoglobin.
body_text.section: Different Classes of Proteins ::: Amino Acids, Peptides, and Proteins ::: Introduction

body_text.text: According to the symmetry of proteins, proteins can be divided into globin and fibrin. Globins are more symmetric and similar to balls or ovals in shape. Globins dissolve easily and can crystallize. Most proteins are globins. Comparatively, fibrins are less symmetric and look like thin sticks or fibers. They can be divided into soluble fibrins and unsolvable fibrins.
body_text.section: Different Classes of Proteins ::: Amino Acids, Peptides, and Proteins ::: Introduction

body_text.text: Simple proteins can be subdivided into seven subclasses: albumin, globulin, glutelin, prolamine, histone, protamine, and scleroprotein. Conjugated proteins can also be subdivided into nucleoprotein, lipoprotein, glycoprotein and mucoprotein, phosphoprotein, hemoprotein, flavoprotein, and metalloprotein. Different classes of proteins have various functions. These include serving as: Catalyzers of metabolism: enzymeStructural component of organismsStorage component of amino acidTransportersMovement proteinsHormonal proteinsImmunological proteinsAcceptor and for transfer of informationRegulatory or control mechanisms for the growth, division, and the expression of genetic information
body_text.section: Different Classes of Proteins ::: Amino Acids, Peptides, and Proteins ::: Introduction

body_text.text: Biological function and biological character are two different concepts. Characters can be shown from a chemical reaction, while functions of molecules are shown by the whole system in several cooperated reactions. Functions are related to the molecule interactions.
body_text.section: Some Noticeable Problems ::: Introduction
The Basic Unit of Protein (Fig. 10.3Fig3fig) ::: Different Levels of Protein Structures ::: Basic Concept of Protein Structure

body_text.text: A peptide bond is made up by connecting an α-COOH of an amino acid and the α-NH3 (Figs. 10.4 and 10.5). The simplest peptide composed of two amino acids is called dipeptide, containing one peptide bond. Those containing three, four, and five peptide bonds are called tripeptide, tetrapeptide, and pentapeptide, respectively. The peptide chain loses a molecule of H2O when forming a peptide bond. In a polypeptide, an amino acid unit is called a residue.
body_text.section: Peptide and Peptide Bond ::: Polypeptide Chain ::: Different Levels of Protein Structures ::: Basic Concept of Protein Structure
The Fold of Polypeptide Chain and Dihedral Angle ::: Polypeptide Chain ::: Different Levels of Protein Structures ::: Basic Concept of Protein Structure
The Imagination of a Polypeptide Chain (Fig. 10.7Fig7fig) ::: Different Levels of Protein Structures ::: Basic Concept of Protein Structure

body_text.text: An amino acid unit in a peptide chain is called a residue.The end having a free α-amino group is called amino-terminal or N-terminal.The end having a free α-carboxyl group is called carboxyl-terminal or C-terminal.By convention, the N-terminal is taken as the beginning of the peptide chain and put at the left (C-terminal at the right). Biosynthesis starts from the N-terminal.
body_text.section: The Peptide Chain Is Directional ::: Different Levels of Protein Structures ::: Basic Concept of Protein Structure

body_text.text: The electronic interaction includes charge-charge interaction, charge-dipole interaction, dipole-dipole interaction, and induced dipole interaction.
body_text.section: The Electronic Interaction of Biological Molecules ::: The Interaction of Biological Molecules ::: Acting Force to Sustain and Stabilize the High-Dimensional Structure of Protein ::: Basic Concept of Protein Structure

The Electronic Interaction of Biological Molecules ::: The Interaction of Biological Molecules ::: Acting Force to Sustain and Stabilize the High-Dimensional Structure of Protein ::: Basic Concept of Protein Structure

body_text.text: Charge-charge interaction
body_text.section: The Electronic Interaction of Biological Molecules ::: The Interaction of Biological Molecules ::: Acting Force to Sustain and Stabilize the High-Dimensional Structure of Protein ::: Basic Concept of Protein Structure

The Electronic Interaction of Biological Molecules ::: The Interaction of Biological Molecules ::: Acting Force to Sustain and Stabilize the High-Dimensional Structure of Protein ::: Basic Concept of Protein Structure

body_text.text: Charge-dipole interaction (Fig. 10.8)
body_text.section: The Electronic Interaction of Biological Molecules ::: The Interaction of Biological Molecules ::: Acting Force to Sustain and Stabilize the High-Dimensional Structure of Protein ::: Basic Concept of Protein Structure
Dipole-Dipole Interaction ::: The Interaction of Biological Molecules ::: Acting Force to Sustain and Stabilize the High-Dimensional Structure of Protein ::: Basic Concept of Protein Structure

body_text.text: Induced dipoles
body_text.section: Dipole-Dipole Interaction ::: The Interaction of Biological Molecules ::: Acting Force to Sustain and Stabilize the High-Dimensional Structure of Protein ::: Basic Concept of Protein Structure
Dipole-Dipole Interaction ::: The Interaction of Biological Molecules ::: Acting Force to Sustain and Stabilize the High-Dimensional Structure of Protein ::: Basic Concept of Protein Structure

body_text.text: Hydration is the process of the subject interacting or combining with water.
body_text.section: The Hydration of Polar Groups ::: The Interaction of Biological Molecules ::: Acting Force to Sustain and Stabilize the High-Dimensional Structure of Protein ::: Basic Concept of Protein Structure

body_text.text: Under the physiological condition, the side chain of acidic amino acid can be broken down into negative ions, while the side chain of basic amino acid can be disassociated into positive ions. Some atoms will form dipoles because of polarization. These interaction forces between charges or dipoles are called electrostatic force and it meets the Coulomb’s law.
body_text.section: Electrostatic Force ::: The Force to Sustain and Stabilize the High-Dimensional Structure of Proteins ::: Acting Force to Sustain and Stabilize the High-Dimensional Structure of Protein ::: Basic Concept of Protein Structure

body_text.text: Van der Waals force can also be called van der Waals bond. It includes attractive force and repulsion force. Van der Waals attractive force is in inverse ratio to the sixth power of the distance between atoms or groups. When they are too close to each other, they will repel each other. The van der Waals bond length is 0.3–0.5 nm. The bond energy is 1–3 kcal/mol.
body_text.section: Van der Waals Force ::: The Force to Sustain and Stabilize the High-Dimensional Structure of Proteins ::: Acting Force to Sustain and Stabilize the High-Dimensional Structure of Protein ::: Basic Concept of Protein Structure

body_text.text: Although the van der Waals force is weak, when the surfaces of two big molecules are close enough to each other, this force is very important. It contributes to sustain the tertiary structure and quaternary structure.
body_text.section: Van der Waals Force ::: The Force to Sustain and Stabilize the High-Dimensional Structure of Proteins ::: Acting Force to Sustain and Stabilize the High-Dimensional Structure of Protein ::: Basic Concept of Protein Structure

body_text.text: In protein solution, if the environment changes, for example, pH, ion strength, or temperature changes, the natural structure of protein may disintegrate and leads to the denaturation of proteins. This process is called protein denaturation. When the condition is normal, if the denatured protein can have their natural structure and character back, then the protein will renature.
body_text.section: The Formation of Protein Structure Level and the Folding of Peptide Chain ::: Different Levels of Protein Structure ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text: The way to make bean curd by heating the solution of bean protein and adding a little salt is an example to make use of the protein denaturation to deposit protein.
body_text.section: The Formation of Protein Structure Level and the Folding of Peptide Chain ::: Different Levels of Protein Structure ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text: According to the classical view, the primary structure of protein decides the high-level structure of proteins. So the high-level structure can be inferred from the primary structure. We can align multiple protein sequences (Table 10.1, Figs. 10.13 and 10.14).
body_text.section: Primary Structure ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text: In the 1980s, when sequences started to accumulate, several labs saw advantages to establishing central repositories. The trouble is many labs thought the same and made their own. The proliferation of databases causes problems. For example, do they have the same format? Which one is the most accurate, up-to-date, and comprehensive? Which one should we use?
body_text.section: Primary Structure ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text: Local organization of protein backbone is α-helix, β-strand (which assembles into β-sheet), turn, and interconnecting loop.
body_text.section: Various Kinds of Protein Secondary Structure ::: Secondary Structure ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text: α-Helix is in a shape of stick. Tightly curled polypeptide backbone forms the inner side of the stick; the side chains expand outside in the form of helix. α-Helix tends to be stable because the hydrogen in NH and the oxygen in the fourth residue CO form hydrogen bond. Each helix contains 3.6 residues. The helix distance is 0.54 nm.
body_text.section: Various Kinds of Protein Secondary Structure ::: Secondary Structure ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text: β-Sheet is another frequently occurrence structure. Two or more fully expended polypeptides cluster together laterally. Hydrogen bond is formed by –NH and C=O on the neighboring peptide backbones. These polypeptide structures are β-sheet. In the β-sheets, all peptides join in the cross-linking between hydrogen bonds. The hydrogen bonds are almost vertical to the long axis of peptide chains. Along the long axis of peptide chain, there are repeated units.
body_text.section: Various Kinds of Protein Secondary Structure ::: Secondary Structure ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text: β-Sheet includes two types. One is the parallel sheet. The arrangement polarization of its peptide chain (N–C) is unidirectional. The N-end of all the peptide chains is in the same direction. Another one is antiparallel. The polarization of the peptide chain is opposite for the neighboring chains.
body_text.section: Various Kinds of Protein Secondary Structure ::: Secondary Structure ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text: In the backbones of polypeptide chain, the structures which are different from the α-helix and β-sheet are called random coil. Random coils mean the irregular peptide chain. For most globins, they often contain a great amount of random coils besides α-helix and β-sheet. In random coils, β-turn is a very important structure.
body_text.section: Various Kinds of Protein Secondary Structure ::: Secondary Structure ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions
Various Kinds of Protein Secondary Structure ::: Secondary Structure ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions
The Variability of Protein Secondary Structure (Figs. 10.15Fig15fig, 10.16Fig16fig, and 10.17Fig17fig) ::: Secondary Structure ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text: Protein databases (PDB) Analysis of main-chain conformations in known protein structure.12,318 residues from 84 proteins, structure 5,712 fell outside the regions of regular structure.Torsion angles (φ,ψ) for the 5,712 residues were calculated and allocated to seven classes in the Ramachandran plot: a,b,e,g,l,p,t ⇒ a,b,e,l,t H, E.Statistical analysis of lengths and conformations of the supersecondary motif. Sequence and conformational data were stored for three successive residues in each of the two elements of secondary structure on either side of the connecting peptide, for example, HHH abl EEE.Classification of the pattern and conformation for supersecondary structure motifs.
body_text.section: High-Frequency Supersecondary Structure Motif ::: Supersecondary Structure ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text: α-α-Hairpin is made up of two almost antiparallel α-helixes connected by a short peptide. This short peptide is usually composed of 1–5 amino acids.
body_text.section: Basic Protein Supersecondary Structure Motif ::: Supersecondary Structure ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text: β-β-Hairpin is made up of two antiparallel β-sheets connected by a short peptide. This peptide is usually composed of 1–5 amino acids.
body_text.section: Basic Protein Supersecondary Structure Motif ::: Supersecondary Structure ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text: α-α-Corner is made up of α-helixes on two different planes connected by a connecting peptide. The vector angle between these two α-helixes is nearly right angle.
body_text.section: Basic Protein Supersecondary Structure Motif ::: Supersecondary Structure ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text: α-β-Arch structure is made up of an α-helix and a β-sheet connected by a short peptide. The most frequently occurring α-β-structure is composed of three parallel β-sheets and two α-helixes. This structure is called Rossmann sheet.
body_text.section: Basic Protein Supersecondary Structure Motif ::: Supersecondary Structure ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text: There are mainly three characteristic descriptions of supersecondary structures: sequence pattern, hydrophobic pattern, and H-bond pattern.
body_text.section: Characteristic Description of Protein Supersecondary Structure ::: Supersecondary Structure ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text: In protein structures, many basic supersecondary structure motifs form some more complicated complexes motif, which are called complicated supersecondary structures.
body_text.section: Complicated Supersecondary Structure Motif ::: Supersecondary Structure ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text: The commonly occurring complicated supersecondary structures include Rossmann fold (Fig. 10.18a), Greek Key topology structure (Fig. 10.18b), and four-helix bundle (Fig. 10.18c), etc. (Figs. 10.19 and 10.20)
body_text.section: Complicated Supersecondary Structure Motif ::: Supersecondary Structure ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text: Polypeptide chains further fold by non-covalent bond interaction and curl into more complicated configuration, which is called tertiary structure.
body_text.section: Protein Tertiary Structure ::: Supersecondary Structure ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text: For bigger protein molecules, polypeptide chains are always composed of two or more independent three-dimensional entity. These entities are called domains.
body_text.section: Protein Tertiary Structure ::: Supersecondary Structure ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text: According to the amount of α-helix and β-sheet, proteins can be divided into four types: α-protein, β-protein, α + β-protein, and α/β-protein (Fig. 10.21).
body_text.section: Protein Tertiary Structure ::: Supersecondary Structure ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text: α-Protein contains more than 40 % of α-helix and less than 10 % of β-sheet (Fig. 10.22a). β-Protein contains more than 40 % of β-sheet and less than 10 % of α-protein (Fig. 10.22b). α + β-Protein contains more than 10 % of α-helix and β-sheet. α,β-Clusters in different regions. α/β-Protein (Fig. 10.22c) contains more than 10 % of α-helix and β-sheet. These two configurations appear in the peptide chain alternatively. The two configurations of different α/β-proteins (Fig. 10.22d) arrange face to face. The shape of the whole molecule varies a lot.
body_text.section: Protein Tertiary Structure ::: Supersecondary Structure ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text: Spatial arrangement of subunits in a protein that contains two or more polypeptide chains is called quaternary structure. It often involves symmetry, but doesn’t have to.
body_text.section: Protein Quaternary Structure ::: Supersecondary Structure ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text: Subunits of proteins form quaternary structure by hydrophobic interaction, H-bond, and van der Waals. The number of most oligomeric proteins is even. There are always one or two types of subunits. The arrangement of most oligomeric protein molecules is symmetric.
body_text.section: Protein Quaternary Structure ::: Supersecondary Structure ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text: Some globins contain two or more polypeptide chain. These polypeptide chains interact with each other, and each of them has their own tertiary structure. These polypeptide chains are subunits of proteins. From the view of structure, subunit is the smallest covalent unit of proteins. Proteins clustered by subunits are called oligomeric proteins. Subunit is the function unit of oligomeric proteins.
body_text.section: Protein Quaternary Structure ::: Supersecondary Structure ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text:
The hierarchy of structural classification (Fig. 10.23): 
Class Similar secondary structure contentAll α, all β, α + β, α/β, etc.
Folds (architecture) Core structure similaritySSEs in similar arrangement
Superfamily (topology) Probable common ancestry
Family Clear evolutionary relationshipSequence similarity >25 %
Individual protein
body_text.section: Structural Classification of Protein Structure ::: Folds ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text:
There are some databanks of structural classification: SCOP Murzin AG, Brenner SE, Hubbard T, and Chothia C.Structural classification of protein structures.Manual assembly by inspection.All nodes are annotated (e.g., all α, α/β).Structural similarity search using 3dSearch (Singh and Brutlag).
CATH Dr. C.A. Orengo, Dr. A.D. Michie, etc.Class-architecture-topology-homologous superfamily.Manual classification at architecture level.Automated topology classification using the SSAP algorithms.No structural similarity search.
FSSP L.L. Holm and C. Sander.Fully automated using the DALI algorithms (Holm and Sander).No internal node annotations.Structural similarity search using DALI.
Pclass A. Singh, X. Liu, J. Chang, and D. Brutlag.Fully automated using the LOCK and 3dSearch algorithms.All internal nodes automatically annotated with common terms.JAVA-based classification browser.Structural similarity search using 3dSearch.
body_text.section: Structural Classification of Protein Structure ::: Folds ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text:
Homologous family: evolutionarily related with a significant sequence identity
Superfamily: different families whose structural and functional features suggest common evolutionary origin
Folds: different superfamilies having the same major secondary structures in the same arrangement and with the same topological connections (energetic favoring certain packing arrangements)
Class: secondary structure composition
body_text.section: Hierarchy of Structure ::: Folds ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text: Proteins have varieties of movements. Movement and structures are the basic elements of protein functions. Protein movement includes short-time and small-amplitude movement, median-time and median-amplitude movement, and long-time and big-amplitude movement (Fig. 10.24).
body_text.section: Protein Molecule Movement and Function ::: Folds ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text: Five schemes of protein three-dimensional structures: The three-dimensional structure of a protein is determined by its amino acid sequence.The function of protein depends on its structure.An isolated protein has a unique or nearly unique structure.The most important forces stabilizing the specific structure of a protein are non-covalent interactions.Amid the huge number of unique protein structures, we can recognize some common structural patterns to improve our understanding of protein architecture.
body_text.section: Summary ::: Fundamental of Macromolecules Structures and Functions

body_text.text: In the following part, we are going to talk about the comparative modeling, inverse folding, ab initio, secondary structure prediction, supersecondary structure prediction, structure-type prediction, and tertiary structure prediction.
body_text.section: Overview ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text: The development and research of life science show that protein peptide chain-folding mechanism is the most important problem to be solved. How does protein fold from primary structure into active natural tertiary structure is waiting to be answered. The elucidation of the protein peptide chain-folding mechanisms is called decoding the second biological code.
body_text.section: The Significance of Protein Structure Prediction ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text: As the human genome and other species genome sequencing plan start and finish, the capacity of databases (e.g., SWISS-PROT) collecting protein sequence increases exponentially. Meanwhile, the capacity of databases (e.g., PDB) collecting protein tertiary crystal structures increases slowly. The increasing rate of the protein sequence number is much greater than that of the known protein structure number. So we need the computational predictive tools to narrow the widening gap.
body_text.section: The Significance of Protein Structure Prediction ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text: In the most genome era, one of the biggest challenges we face is to discover the structure and function of every protein in the genome plan. So, predicting protein structure theoretically becomes one way to decrease the disparity between protein structure and sequence.
body_text.section: The Significance of Protein Structure Prediction ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text: Why should we predict secondary structure? Because it is an easier problem than 3D structure prediction (more than 40 years of history) and accurate secondary structure prediction can be important information for the tertiary structure prediction. Ever since the first work of prediction of secondary structure done by Chou-Fasman, it has been 30 years. The accuracy is around 60 %. Since 1990s, several machine learning algorithms have been successfully applied to the prediction of protein secondary structure and the accuracy reaches 70 %. From this, we can see a good method can help improve the prediction result significantly.
body_text.section: The Significance of Protein Structure Prediction ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text: There are a few prediction methods including statistical method (Chou-Fasman method, GOR I-IV), nearest neighbors (NNSSP, SSPAL, Fuzzy-logic-based method), neural network (PHD (Fig. 10.25), Psi-Pred, J-Pred), support vector machine (SVM), and HMM.
body_text.section: The Significance of Protein Structure Prediction ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text: There are many researches in this field. V. Vapnik [1] developed a promising learning theory (Statistical Learning Theory (SLT)) based on the analysis of the nature of machine. Support vector machine (SVM) is an efficient implementation of SLT. SVM has been successfully applied to a wide range of pattern recognition problems, including isolated handwritten digit recognition, object recognition, speaker identification, and text categorization.
body_text.section: Support Vector Machine ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text: For the linearly separable case (Fig. 10.27), the SVM tries to look for one unique separating hyperplane, which is maximal in the margin between the vectors of the two classes. This hyperplane is called Optimal Separating Hyperplane (OSH) (Fig. 10.28).
body_text.section: Support Vector Machine ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction
Support Vector Machine ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction
Support Vector Machine ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction
Support Vector Machine ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text:
For the linearly non-separable case, the SVM performs a nonlinear mapping of the input vectors from the input space R
d into a high-dimensional feature space H and the mapping is determined by a kernel function. Then like the linearly separable case, it finds the OSH in the higher-dimensional feature space H.
body_text.section: Support Vector Machine ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction
Support Vector Machine ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction
Support Vector Machine ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction
Support Vector Machine ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction
The Empirical Risk Minimization (ERM) ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction
The Structural Risk Minimization (SRM) ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text: The data sets
body_text.section: New Approach to Protein Secondary Structure Prediction ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text: Two nonhomologous data sets: The RS126 set – percentage identity – 25 %The CB513 set – the SD (or Z) score – 5
body_text.section: New Approach to Protein Secondary Structure Prediction ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text: We exclude entries if: They are not determined by X-ray diffraction.The program DSSP could not produce an output.The protein had physical chain breaks.They had a resolution worse than 0.19 nm.
body_text.section: New Approach to Protein Secondary Structure Prediction ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text: Now the automatic assignments of secondary structure to the experimentally determined 3D structure are usually performed by DSSP, STRIDE, or DEFINE.
body_text.section: Assignments of the Protein Secondary Structure ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text: Here we concentrate exclusively on the DSSP assignments, which distinguish eight secondary structure classes: H (α-helix), G (310-helix), I (π-helix), E (β-strand), B (isolated β-bridge), T (turn), S (bend), and (the rests).
body_text.section: Assignments of the Protein Secondary Structure ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text: We reduce the eight classes to three states – helix (H), sheet (E), and coil (C) according to two different methods: DSSP: H, G, and I to H; E to E; and all other states to CDSSP: H and G to H, E and B to E, and all other states to C
body_text.section: Assignments of the Protein Secondary Structure ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text: Cross-validation trials are necessary to minimize variation in results caused by a particular choice of training or test sets.
body_text.section: Assessment of Prediction Accuracy ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text:
A full jackknife test is not feasible, especially on the CB513 set for the limited computation power. We take the sevenfold cross-validation on both sets. 
Q_index (Q3, QH, QE,QC)Matthews’ Correlation Coefficient (CH, CE, CC)Segment Overlap Measure (SOV)
body_text.section: Assessment of Prediction Accuracy ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction
Assessment of Prediction Accuracy ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text: For the case of the single sequence, each residue is coded by the orthogonal binary vector (1,0,…,0) or (0,1,…,0). The vector is 21-dimensional. If the window length is l, the dimensionality of the feature vector (or the sample space) is 21*l. When we include the evolutionary information, for each residue the frequency of occurrence of each of the 20 amino acids at one position in the alignment is computed.
body_text.section: The Coding Scheme ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text: We design six binary classifiers (SVMs) as follows: Helix/non-helix – H/∼ HSheet/non-sheet – E/∼ ECoil/non-coil – C/∼ CHelix/sheet – H/ESheet/coil – E/CCoil/helix – C/H
body_text.section: The Design of Binary Classifiers ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text:
Assembly of the binary classifiers: SVM_MAX_DWe combined the three one-versus-rest classifiers (H/∼H, E/∼E, and C/∼C) to handle the multiclass case. The class (H, E, or C) for a testing sample was assigned as that corresponding to the largest positive distance to the OSH.SVM_TREE (Fig. 10.32) 
SVM_NN (Fig. 10.33)
body_text.section: The Design of Tertiary Classifiers ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text: The tertiary classifiers we designed:
body_text.section: The Design of Tertiary Classifiers ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction
Results and Analysis ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text: Accuracy measure
body_text.section: Results and Analysis ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction
Results and Analysis ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text: Improvement of accuracy:
body_text.section: Results and Analysis ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction
Results and Analysis ::: The Field of Machine Learning ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text: Threading (or inverse folding) method can be used to predict structure without homology information. The basic assumption is that the folding type of natural protein is limited. So we can align the sequence of proteins whose structures are unknown and those proteins whose structures are known. And then predict on the best alignment. This method cannot predict new types of proteins correctly.
body_text.section: Threading Method ::: Homological Protein Structure Prediction Method ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text: Threading method can be done by summarizing known independent protein structure patterns as the model of unknown structure and then by learning known database to summarize average potential function which can distinguish correction and error. In this way we can get the best alignment way.
body_text.section: Threading Method ::: Homological Protein Structure Prediction Method ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text: Protein sequence incrustation: Basing on the experience method. Build various potential functions by analyzing protein of known structure, and see if it can align with known structure by using the standard of lowest folding configuration to guide the object protein sequence incrustation.Basing on the 3D profile. Predict sequence space structure by building a 3D profile, using dynamic programming, comparing new sequence with those in profile databases, and seeking optimal alignment.
body_text.section: Threading Method ::: Homological Protein Structure Prediction Method ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text: Protein secondary structure prediction research has developed for more than three decades. From the progression of research method, there are three different periods. The first period is statistic prediction basing on single residue; the second period, statistic prediction basing on sequence segments; and the third period, statistic prediction combining evolutionary information.
body_text.section: Protein Secondary Structure Prediction ::: Ab Initio Prediction Method ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text: Rost and Sander (1993) promoted prediction basing on neural network – PHD (Profile fed neural network systems from HeiDelberg). It is the first method with the prediction accuracy over 70 %, first efficient method bringing in evolutionary method, and one of the most accurate methods so far.
body_text.section: Protein Secondary Structure Prediction ::: Ab Initio Prediction Method ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text: PHD is a complicated method basing on neural network. It includes poly-sequence information. Recently, Cuff and Barton synthesize many good secondary prediction methods, such as DSC, NNSSP, PREDATOR, and PHD. Up to now, there are still some other artificial intelligence methods to predict secondary structure, such as expert system and nearest neighbor method.
body_text.section: Protein Secondary Structure Prediction ::: Ab Initio Prediction Method ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text: Recently, it is a good opportunity to predict protein secondary structure. For one thing, structural genomic plan is carried out throughout the world to increase the speed of measuring the number of protein structure and fold type. For another, the field of machine learning develops fast. For example, in recent 2 years, the building and perfecting of famous statistic learning theory of V. Vapnik make it possible for us to use the latest machine learning method to improve the prediction accuracy of secondary structure.
body_text.section: Protein Secondary Structure Prediction ::: Ab Initio Prediction Method ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction

body_text.text: Our paper published on JMB (J. Mol. Biol.) applied SVM to predict protein secondary structure and got an accuracy of 76.2 %.
body_text.section: Protein Secondary Structure Prediction ::: Ab Initio Prediction Method ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction
Chou-Fasman Method ::: Ab Initio Prediction Method ::: Basis of Protein Structure and Function Prediction
